item.title: Welcome To The Pain Cave | Quality Bicycle Products
item.description:
Welcome To The Pain Cave | Quality Bicycle Products

The time of year when many cease riding in the elements and retire to their pain caves is nearly upon us. With that comes trainer season for your shop. Setting up the perfect pain cave is considered an art form by many.

item.title: Shop Window: Go 1x with Wolf Tooth for Shimano
item.description:
Shop Window: Go 1x with Wolf Tooth for Shimano

Wolf Tooth Components' Drop-Stop one-by chainrings are now available for Dura-Ace, Ultegra, 105, and Tiagra cranks with Shimano's asymmetric 4x110mm bolt pattern. Machined from hard-wearing 7075-T6 aluminum in Minneapolis, Minnesota, the chainrings take advantage of Wolf Tooth's patent-pending Drop-StopÂ® tooth profile for chain retention and mud shedding.

item.title: Cyclists Survival Guide
item.description:
Cyclists Survival Guide

Oregon Department of Transportation (ODOT) just released a pretty great guide for bike commuters. Though it specifically deals with Oregon road law, the suggestions are basic enough they could apply elsewhere in the U.S. as well. The Bicyclist's Survival Guide (see the full PDF here) is nicely organized with four main sections and great safety tips in each.

item.title: Why Bike Commuting Is Taking Off In The Nation's Car Capital
item.description:
Why Bike Commuting Is Taking Off In The Nation's Car Capital

Since 2006, Detroit has painted 170 miles of new bike lanes on city streets. People on bikes followed: The Motor City now has the fastest-growing rate of bike commuters in the country. Bike commuting grew over 400% in Detroit from 2000 to 2014, according to a new report the American League of Bicyclists, which pulled from census data.

item.title: Artisanal Organic Free-Range Whathaveyous
item.description:
Artisanal Organic Free-Range Whathaveyous

Ah, the Pacific Northwest, home of fashion-forward flannel, the fancy donut "trend" (weren't they always kinda fancy?) Twin Peaks (truly crucial to call out) and our personal favorite: some real deal dyed-in-the-wool Surly Superfans.

item.title: The Gear You Need to Prevent Your Bike from Ever Being Stolen
item.description:
The Gear You Need to Prevent Your Bike from Ever Being Stolen

A recent spate of bike thefts in Santa Fe has us thinking about bicycle security. The good news: Over the past decade, the number of bikes reported stolen in the United States has decreased every year except two (2011 and 2012), according to FBI statistics.

item.title: Why Cycle Oklahoma Bicycle Route 66?
item.description:
Why Cycle Oklahoma Bicycle Route 66?

October 27, 2015 Why would I want to ride in Oklahoma? Well, my three buddies and I, one a persuasive Sooner, chose to ride there as part of our annual "Old Guys Tour." Two facts clinched the deal: one, Adventure Cycling had just released its Bicycle Route 66 maps and, two, Oklahoma would be the 47th state of my 50 state bicycle quest.

item.title: Maxin' And Relaxin' At Grinduro
item.description:
Maxin' And Relaxin' At Grinduro

When was the last time you saw carbon fiber, disc brake-equipped cyclocross bikes racing alongside full suspension mountain bikes? Not to mention handmade works of art from California's best independent frame builders, full-on road racing bikes, singlespeeds, at least one fixed gear and even a tandem.

item.title: Denverites say they'd shop more on Broadway with a protected bike lane
item.description:
Denverites say they'd shop more on Broadway with a protected bike lane

October 23, 2015 Michael Andersen, Green Lane Project staff writer Photo: Bike Denver. From Portland to New York to Salt Lake City, the story is the same: the less a street resembles a freeway, the likelier people are to spend money there.
